verses.text: The LORD spoke to Moses, saying:
verses.comment: God directly addresses Moses. The style is consistent with previous places where God gives commands to His chosen leader. Compare with Lev. 27:26 and Num. 3:13, showing God's authority to claim what is first and most precious.

verses.text: "Consecrate to Me every firstborn, whichever opens the womb among the Israelites, both man and animal; it belongs to Me."
verses.comment: The action of consecrating the firstborn underscores God's right over life, especially after the Passover event. See Luke 2:23, where Jesus' presentation in the Temple follows this command, prefiguring greater spiritual realities.

verses.text: Then Moses said to the people, "Remember this day, the day you came out of Egypt, out of the house of slavery, for with a strong hand the LORD brought you out from there. No leavened bread shall be eaten.
verses.comment: The requirement to avoid leaven is a memorial of their hasty departure but also represents purity. This ritual is foundational for later worship patterns and prefigures future memorials, see 1 Cor. 5:7-8 on unleavened bread as a symbol of sincerity and truth.

verses.text: Today, in the month of Abib, you are going out.
verses.comment: The reference to the month of Abib (later called Nisan) connects this event with the Jewish calendar. This dating is used to set the rhythm of annual worship, emphasizing the importance of commemorating salvation events.

verses.text: When the LORD brings you into the land of the Canaanites, Hittites, Amorites, Hivites, and Jebusites, the land He swore to your fathers to give you, a land flowing with milk and honey, you shall observe this service in this month.
verses.comment: God's promise to Abraham's descendants is repeated. Observing ritual acts is connected to occupying the promised land, showing worship and obedience walk together with the fulfillment of God's promises.

verses.text: Seven days you shall eat unleavened bread, and on the seventh day there shall be a feast to the LORD.
verses.comment: The seven-day observance mirrors the pattern of creation and sanctification of time. The final feast emphasizes the communal and liturgical nature of Israelite worship, hinting at the importance of ongoing liturgical celebrations.

verses.text: Unleavened bread shall be eaten for seven days; no leavened bread shall be seen among you, nor shall any leaven be seen within your borders.
verses.comment: Such thoroughness in removing leaven stresses a separation from sin and a call to moral purity, as taught in the New Testament by Paul—see 1 Cor. 5:7.

verses.text: You shall tell your son on that day, 'It is because of what the LORD did for me when I came out of Egypt.'
verses.comment: Parental responsibility in teaching faith is central—ritual observance is to be accompanied by clear explanation, nurturing faith across generations as a living tradition.

verses.text: It shall be for you as a sign on your hand and as a reminder between your eyes, so that the LORD's law may be in your mouth. For with a strong hand the LORD brought you out of Egypt.
verses.comment: Physical acts and observable signs reinforce inner spiritual realities. See also Deut. 6:8; this foreshadows the use of visible signs and sacraments in worship.

verses.text: You shall therefore keep this statute at its appointed time year after year.
verses.comment: Regular, annual remembrance establishes community identity. The continuity of worship is portrayed as commanded by God himself.

verses.text: When the LORD brings you into the land of the Canaanites, just as He swore to you and your fathers, and gives it to you,
verses.comment: The inheritance of the land depends on God's faithfulness to his covenant. The phrase links salvation history to the concept of a chosen people and continuation of promises.

verses.text: then you shall set apart to the LORD every firstborn of the womb. All the firstborn of your livestock that are males shall be the LORD's.
verses.comment: Setting apart the firstborn is an act of stewardship and recognition of God's ultimate ownership—spiritually, this points toward the offering of the best to God, a principle foundational in sacrificial systems and later worship forms.

verses.text: Every firstborn of a donkey you shall redeem with a lamb, and if you do not redeem it you must break its neck. Every firstborn of man among your sons you shall redeem.
verses.comment: Redemption is key: unclean animals and humans are redeemed by substitution—a clear precursor for later sacrificial theology and the understanding of Christ’s own redemptive sacrifice.

verses.text: And when in the future your son asks you, ‘What does this mean?’ you shall say to him, ‘By a strong hand the LORD brought us out of Egypt, out of the house of slavery.’
verses.comment: The pedagogy of faith: children are to be formed in the story and practices, modeling faith as both inherited and explained. Compare Eph. 6:4’s call to bring up children in discipline and instruction.

verses.text: For when Pharaoh stubbornly refused to let us go, the LORD killed all the firstborn in the land of Egypt, both the firstborn of man and of animal. Therefore I sacrifice to the LORD all the males that open the womb, but all the firstborn of my sons I redeem.
verses.comment: Ritual and remembrance are joined: Israel’s offering of the firstborn recalls God’s deliverance through judgment and mercy. The notion of redemption finds deeper fulfillment in the New Testament (Heb. 9:12-14).

verses.text: So it shall be as a sign on your hand and as frontlets between your eyes, for by a strong hand the LORD brought us out of Egypt.
verses.comment: Tangible signs are used to carry spiritual truths, teaching that faith is expressed in outward rituals—visible reminders reinforcing inner realities. See James 2:18: faith is shown in visible works.

verses.text: When Pharaoh let the people go, God did not lead them by way of the land of the Philistines, though it was near; for God said, 'Lest the people change their minds when they see war and return to Egypt.'
verses.comment: God’s providence allows for humanity’s weakness; He leads not always by the shortest but by the best way. Spiritual formation requires trust and patience.

verses.text: But God led the people around by the way of the wilderness toward the Red Sea. The people of Israel went up out of the land of Egypt armed for battle.
verses.comment: Even as they are prepared externally, God’s design refines their interior faith, showing that readiness is not only about physical means but trust in divine guidance.

verses.text: Moses took the bones of Joseph with him, for Joseph had made the sons of Israel swear solemnly, saying, 'God will surely visit you, and you shall carry up my bones with you from here.'
verses.comment: Joseph’s bones are a sign of continuity between the patriarchal promises and their fulfillment—demonstrating the importance of physical reminders (relics and memorials) in salvation history.

verses.text: They set out from Succoth and camped at Etham, on the edge of the wilderness.
verses.comment: The narrative detail roots the journey in real geography, marking the stages of Israel’s exodus—historical acts that lay groundwork for ongoing traditions and pilgrimage.

verses.text: The LORD went before them by day in a pillar of cloud to lead them along the way, and by night in a pillar of fire to give them light, so that they might travel by day and by night.
verses.comment: God’s presence is visible and guiding—a prefiguration of later belief in the real and continuous presence of God with His people, culminating in New Testament realities (see Rev. 21:23).

verses.text: He did not take away the pillar of cloud by day or the pillar of fire by night from before the people.
verses.comment: This enduring presence foreshadows God’s promises of constant guidance and protection, and points forward to the ways He continues to be visibly present among His people even now.
